questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Phone System and Calling Plans.
You plan to implement a toll phone number for the helpdesk.
You need to implement the following call features for the helpdesk phone number:
✑ Must include a greeting and hold music
✑ Must bypass menu options when a call is established to the helpdesk
What two resources should you create? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
A and D.
Auto attendant and call queue require a resource account to be associated in order to assign the phone number.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-call-queue
'You don't directly associate a phone number to a call queue, instead the phone number is associated to a resource account. A call queue can be dialed directly or accessed by a selection on an auto attendant.'

Menu is only available for auto attendant, so therefore call queue does not have a menu option.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-call-queue
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-auto-attendant

A&D - There is no requirement for an AutoAttendant. No menu specified.
A User calling a Toll Number (i.E. from PSTN) means a licensed Ressource Account is required that carries the phone Number and which is associated to a Call Queue.

The CQ has the features required (Greeting and music on Hold, no menu)

Resource account option is correct. But the bypass menu options is what is throwing me off. That’s pointing towards an auto attendant with an operator (help desk) configured. I do agree that help desk should be setup as a call queue, but what menu options are there in a call queue? There is no press 1 for this, press 2 for that.

So although I would set up the solution the same way, when asking for a menu, I think the answer should be resource account and auto attendant.

comments.content: Reading it again “Must bypass menu options when a call is established to the helpdesk” might mean there shouldn’t be any menu options at all when calling the help desk. If that’s the intended meaning, then yes call queue and resource account is the correct answer.

discussion.content: Was on test on 22.08.2022
A resource account is not a resource in itself...they ask for resources here...so I think it should be CQ and AA..
On Test 18.01.22

Call queues are waiting areas for callers. For situations where callers need to reach someone with a particular specialty - such as sales or service - rather than a specific person, you can use call queues to connect callers to the group of agents who can assist them. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/plan-auto-attendant-call-queue
A and D.

comments.content: Nope they ask for music, you need a Call Queue for this

discussion.content: I think C and D. you need an Auto Attendant who is dependent on a resource account. There is no mention that the Queue is in the MS phone system. It could be an external call Q hosted on another phone system in another company.
Auto Attendant has Menu options, Call queue doesnt have it. since question is to bypass Menu options, Call queue and resource account (A&D)
A & D si correct

It is A & D

You need the Call queue (A) and this queue has to following pre-requisites:
To configure auto attendants and call queues, you need the following resources:

A resource account for each auto attendant and each call queue -->D
A free Phone System - Virtual User license for each resource account
At least one Microsoft service number, direct routing number, or a hybrid number for each resource account that you want to be directly dialable
The service number may be a toll or toll-free number

"Must bypass menu options": I think it means there is an existing auto attendant menu, and when a call is made to the helpdesk, it does not go to the menu, it goes to the helpdesk call queue. So, you don't need a new auto attendant, just a call queue with resource account.
the questions states which 2 resources u should create not what should u do ..then the corrected answer should be A,C

comments.content: One of the requirements was to bypass menus, isn't AA all about menus? All requirements are fulfilled with a queue, making it A & D (resource account needed for the phone number).
A resource account is required for AA and call queues

discussion.content:
AC
B: Call park is to put the call on hold.
D: Resource account is for meeting rooms etc.
E: Calling policy control what the user can or cannot do during a call.
Auto attendants let people call your organization and navigate a menu system to speak to the right department, call queue, person, or an operator. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-auto-attendant
Cloud call queues can provide:
• A greeting message.
• Music while people are waiting on hold.
• Redirecting calls to call agents in mail-enabled distribution lists and security groups.
• Setting different parameters such as queue maximum size, timeout, and call handling options.
• Shared voicemail for callers to leave a message for an organization.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-call-queue
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-calling-policy

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to create the call queues shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Which routing method should you configure for each call queue? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Attendant routing rings all agents in the queue at the same time. The first call agent to pick up the call gets the call.

Serial routing rings all call agents one by one in the order specified in the Call agents list. If an agent dismisses or does not pick up a call, the call will ring the next agent and will try all agents until it is picked up or times out.

Round robin balances the routing of incoming calls so that each call agent gets the same number of calls from the queue. This may be desirable in an inbound sales environment to assure equal opportunity among all the call agents.

Longest idle routes each call to the agent who has been idle the longest time. An agent is considered idle if their presence state is Available or if their presence state has been Away for less than 10 minutes. Agents whose presence state has been Away for more than 10 minutes are not considered idle and will not be eligible to receive calls until they change their presence to Available.

Answer is Correct
Attendant routing is first call in the queue rings all agents at the same time (Simultaneously)
Round robin - routing of incoming calls is balance so that each call gets the same numbers of call from the queue.

Selected Answer: D
Tested. 

Answer is D

Selected Answer: D

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams and contains a user named User1.
User1 reports that the Meeting recording button is missing from the Microsoft Teams client. The user cannot record meetings.
You need to ensure that User1 meets the prerequisites to record Microsoft Teams meetings.
What should you do?

choices.C: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, enter Diag: Missing Recording in the Need help? search box.
choices.D: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, enter Diag: Meeting Recording in the Need help? search box.
choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, use the Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).
choices.B: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, use Teams advisor.

discussion.content:
Debug, Desktop, and Media logs will be collected in one folder with the name MSTeams Diagnostics Log <local date and time>. This folder can be compressed and shared when you open a support request with Microsoft Support. The folder will contain folders for Desktop, Meeting (Media), and Debug (web). You can collect the files using the following keyboard shortcuts:

Ctrl + Alt + Shift + 1
confirmed that B is the correct answer. I just did this on my Teams client and logs were downloaded. Ctrl+Alt+Shift+1

Straight forward answer. D does not allow to collect log, B allows to collect log.
If there were two choices to select, then B and D.
Yes D for screen sharing issues, but they asking to collect logs, D along wouldn't create and download the logs.

Answer B

Media logs contain diagnostic data about audio, video, and screen sharing in Teams meetings. They are required for support cases that are linked to call-related issues.
Should be D

Media logging is turned off by default. To log diagnostic data for Teams meetings, users must turn on the option in the Teams client. Go to Settings > General, select the Enable logging for meeting diagnostics (requires restarting Teams) check box, restart Teams, and reproduce the issue.
Screen sharing could be media logs? In this case could be D?
On Exam 28.02.22

You will need to view the Microsoft Teams debug logs to troubleshoot the issues. Or, if you are the End User, this is how to get the logs to send to your Support Engineers to troubleshoot.
Open Microsoft Teams, and on your keyboard, select Ctrl+Alt+Shift+1
They are talking about about Sharing screen, which would be video related and hence require you to enable logging for meeting diagnostics. Answer: D
I think answer D is wrong since the question is asking for the client logs and NOT for the debug logs, which we get with answer B.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams.
A user reports an error when he attempts to share his screen during meetings by using the Microsoft Teams Windows Desktop client.
You need to collect the Microsoft Teams client log files from the user's device.
What should you do?

choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams client settings, select Disable GPU hardware acceleration.
choices.C: Select the Windows logo key + Alt + Shift +1.
choices.D: From the Microsoft Teams client settings, select Enable logging for meeting diagnostics.

choices.B: The source port for audio is above 50,000.
choices.A: The source port range for audio is too narrow.
choices.C: The UDP traffic is being limited.
choices.D: The TLS traffic is being limited.

questions.question_text:
Users report poor quality during Microsoft Teams audio conferences.
You run a network trace during an audio conference from a user's device as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

What causes the poor quality of the audio conferences?

discussion.content:
If a frame has Sequence number and ACK, it means that the protocol is TCP and not UDP. (UDP doesn't have these in it's header)

-> C is correct, because Teams forces TCP only when UDP traffic is limited/blocked

comments.content: This is correct! The output here is TCP instead of UDP.
I don't know if I'd call TCP a 'generic' term, but otherwise you make a fair point. If you don't know what TCP is, you might want to do a basic networking course first.

agreed. I would say it was a common (and tbh fairly low level) term, rather than a generic one (although I suppose it could be considered generic insomuch as it is not vendor-specific), but if a person doesn't know it, then this probably isn't an exam they should be sitting.

TCP and failback are generic IT terms, there is an assumption that if you are sitting these exams you are proficient in general IT terms and concepts. At the very least you should be able to fire up Wireshark, capture some packets and play back the audio contained within them. If you can't then I suggest you have a go rather than just brain dumping.

But what does that actually mean? I'm finding a lot of these Microsoft Learn acticles are not thought out well and are littered with jargon. They assume too much of the learner. I have no idea what TCP is, or what 'failback transport' is, or for that matter what 'stateful nature' means.

discussion.content:
Network trace is showing TCP traffic:

"TCP is considered a failback transport and not the primary transport you want for real-time media. The reason it’s a failback transport is due to the stateful nature of TCP. For example, if a call is made on a latent network and media packets are delayed, then packets from a few seconds ago—which are no longer useful—compete for bandwidth to get to the receiver, which can make a bad situation worse. This makes the audio healer stitch and stretch audio, resulting in audible artifacts, often in the form of jitter."

Source: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/quality-of-experience-review-guide#quality-investigations

Cualquier plataforma que haga uso de telefonía IP necesita un rango de puertos UDP amplio: estas plataformas como Teams, están pensadas para un rango potencial de llamadas y usuarios bastante elevado, y cada llamada (sesión de audio, video,..) utiliza varios puertos UDP. De ahí que requieran un rango muy amplio.

Look at DstPort: it says port 443, it is using TCP port. UDP ports must be used for audio and video. UDP guarantees quality communication. Example: if the road of my voice or my image has a lot of traffic, it will take a long time to get from source to destination: the voice will not be heard in real time, it arrives late, it is cut, and the image freezes, it is blocked: this is TCP: the car goes slow on the road if there is traffic. The UDP port sends the information always, it does not wait for the road to be clear. Imagine that it is an ambulance: it always has priority they must let them pass - this is UDP. It is very common for FWs to block UDP traffic, because a very wide open range of ports is needed.

I can see people asking about how people know this is TCP and not UDP. In my opinion before you take this exam you should be able to spot TCP and UDP ports quite easily from numbers. Sorry if that's in any way condescending.

Selected Answer: C
Agree with C
How can we know this isn't a signaling packet? If it's a voice packet, I agree it should be UDP instead of TCP. But signaling is always TCP.

udp is the protocol used for real-time communications - so as stated by OrwellMB if you can see a problem with the udp protocol as in this example where TCP is employed meaning udp is not which implies a problem with the udp protocol

TCP: Sends a packet > waits for an acknowledgment from destination > sends the next packet (also known as 3 way handshake) | No packets are lost | Slow and not handy in real time traffic | e.g. Emails use TCP 
UDP: Sends all packets in a single go | Doesnt care about acknowledgment hence sometimes looses few packets on the way | Ideal for real time traffic like audio and video calls.

The fact that TCP is present in mentioned question, indicates that there is no real time traffic exchange between source and destination. Hence the UDP traffic (or real time traffic) is limited.

C is correct. DstPort in the log is 443 that means TCP is used and TCP is just a failback.

Check this:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges?view=o365-worldwide#skype-for-business-online-and-microsoft-teams
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/quality-of-experience-review-guide#quality-investigations

Audio streams should not use TCP port 443 as destination port, they should use preferably UDP ports 3478 through 3481. The audio stream will only failback to TCP port 443 if the UDP ports 3478 through 3481 are blocked in the firewall or something like that.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/m365-teams-upgrade-plan-upgrade/prepare-network
C is correct, because TCP is fail back if UDP failed, we get it as a TCP from the Dst port:443

comments.content: I think C, they're just explaining why it's the case. Idk how they see TCP traffic though lol

discussion.content: So what is the right answer. Can anyone please get share a link to understand the network trace.Thanks

Sizz is 100s correct. Microsoft also recommends that you bypass any proxy servers for all Teams services. Although using a proxy might work from a Security perspective, Media will be forced to use TCP instead of UDP, which will result in a reduction in quality.
